Award.AwardTitle: Collective Efficacy and Norm Violation: An Experimental Test

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES- 1625273
Ross Matsueda
University of Washington

This project examines an important question for social science theory and criminal justice policy: Does disorder in a community foster criminal and deviant behavior. Or is community efficacy responsible for both disorder and crime. The researchers approach this question by embedding field experiments with neighborhoods that vary by social capital and community efficacy. The answers to these questions have important intellectual payoffs and policy implications. Intellectually, the project will provide an important test of the broken windows hypothesis in criminology disorder is a cause of crime and norm violations versus the collective efficacy hypothesis disorder and crime are each caused by community efficacy, and therefore, disorder is spuriously related to crime. The project will yield stronger causal statements than previous research because it uses experimental methods. The project has important policy implications. If disorder causes crime directly, then zero-tolerance policing in which police focus on cleaning up streets of panhandlers, broken windows, graffiti, and other signs of disorder is called for. If disorder and crime are not causally related but are instead each caused by community efficacy, then policies of community empowerment increasing community resources, social ties, and civic participation are called for. The researchers are incorporating diverse and underrepresented students in the research process and working with the city of Seattle to disseminate their results.

To test broken windows theory against collective efficacy, the investigators will conduct experiments in multiple neighborhoods, capitalizing on their survey measures of collective efficacy and disadvantage. Five experiments will examine whether the presence of disorder (graffiti and litter on the ground)affects norm violating behavior. (1) A Letter Drop, in which 24 stamped addressed letters are dropped in each of 123 census tracts. Half will be dropped within sight of graffiti. The mail back rate provides a measure of collective efficacy, as well as a test of whether physical disorder (graffiti) impedes prosocial activity. (2) A Lost Envelope Experiment, in which an envelope with a visible $5 bill enclosed is placed near a mailbox, and passersby can either ignore, mail or steal the envelope. The treatment condition, graffiti and litter nearby, tests whether disorder promotes theft and impedes prosocial behavior. (3) A "Litter Cam," in which a time-elapse camera will record time-to-cleanup in a setting filled with litter. The hypothesis tested is that time to clean up will be shorter in collectively efficacious neighborhoods. The treatment condition "graffiti in the vicinity" tests whether additional disorder impedes acts of collective efficacy. (4) Intervening During an Act of Littering, in which a confederate (varied by race and gender) is observed littering in front of local passersby. The outcome is whether passersby interrupt the confederate. We test the hypothesis that the race/gender of the litterer interacts with the race/gender of the intervener. (5) Littering a Flyer on a Car, in which a flyer placed on windshields of parked cars is either littered or not. The treatment, disorder (graffiti), tests the broken windows hypothesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social and physical disorder are correlated with neighborhood crime.  A popular interpretation of this correlation is known as "the broken windows thesis," which argues that minor incivilities, such as littering, graffiti, and loitering, signal to potential criminals that local neighborhoods are indifferent to the problem of crime.  Consequently, minor incivilities produce a cascade of crimes, including serious crime. The policy implication of this thesis is zero-tolerance policing, in which police crack down on littering, graffiti, and loitering to stop the genesis of serious crime. A competing perspective, associated with collective efficacy theory, argues that neighborhood disorder does not cause serious crime.  Instead, organized neighborhoods rich in social ties are able to act collectively to reduce disorder as well as crime.  Conversely, disorganized neighborhoods are able to deal with neither disorder nor crime. 

 A landmark study by Keizer et al (2008), published in Science, used field experiments in a single neighborhood in Groningen to show that disorder (e.g. litter and graffiti) is associated with norm violations (e.g., theft of an envelope), supporting the broken windows thesis.  This project seeks to replicate and extend these results by conducting similar experiments across multiple neighborhoods in Seattle.  It conducted a mailbox experiment, following Keizer et al.?s study, placing a large stamped envelope with a $5 bill visible in the address window next to a U.S. mailbox.  In the control condition, researchers observed passersby and recorded whether they ignored the envelope, mailed the envelope (a prosocial act), or stole the envelope (an antisocial act).  The treatment condition spread graffiti and litter on the sidewalk.  The results failed to replicate Keizer et al:  Passersby were no more likely to steal the envelope in the presence of graffiti and litter than in the control condition of a clean sidewalk.  Instead, they were less likely to mail the envelope in the presence of graffiti and litter, suggesting that neighborhood disorder impedes pro-social behavior.  These results fail to support broken windows and provide some support for collective efficacy.

 Research on collective efficacy has measured collective efficacy using survey items administered to neighborhood residents.  Rarely has the process of collective efficacy--intervening in norm-violating behavior on behalf of the common good--been examined.  In particular, no research has examined whether collective efficacy--intervening when others commit deviance or incivilities--varies by the characteristics of the perpetrator.  Are Seattle residents neighborhoods more reluctant to intervene when a black person is violating a norm?  We found that bystanders were reluctant to intervene when the litterer was a black male, compared to white male or white female.  We did not, however, find that interventions varied by whether litter and graffiti were present. Interventions were also not correlated with neighborhood rates of collective efficacy.

 Finally, given the reliability issues endemic in survey research, an important question has asked whether collective efficacy can be measured without resorting to survey methods. To explore this, we attempted to replicate Milgram et al.'s (1965) classic "lost letter" experiment (see also Sampson 2012).  We dropped 24 letters in each of 122 Census tracts in Seattle.  Each letter was stamped and randomly-addressed to one of three conditions:  (1) a personal letter (N = 979); (2) the American Neo-Nazi Party (N = 979); and (3) Friends of Black Lives Matter (N=980).  The dependent variable is whether or not the lost letter was returned.  The independent variables include the addressee condition and characteristics of the Census tract (racial composition, disadvantage, collective efficacy).  The results replicated Milgram et al.'s study remarkably:  return rates were 58% for Seattle, compared to 48 percent for Milgram for New Haven, and 33% for Sampson for Chicago.  Consistent with Milgram, return rates were 79% for the personal letter, 71% for the Black Lives Matter letters, and 24% for the American Neo-Nazi Party. Moreover the return rates were correlated substantially (.34) with collective efficacy measured 12 years earlier, supporting the notion of collective efficacy as pro-social behavior, and emblematic of the "good society" (Sampson 2012). 

In sum, our results fail to replicate Keizer et al.'s support for the broken windows thesis--disorder is not associated with theft--suggesting that policies of zero-tolerance policing should perhaps be reconsidered.  We do find some support for collective efficacy theory:  disorder undermines prosocial behavior, and the prosocial acts of mailing lost letters is associated with neighborhood collective efficacy.
